docs.lead_paragraph: The way prosecutors told it in court yesterday, Karlie DiTrapani killed her baby minutes after secretly giving birth to him in a bathroom of her Brooklyn home, after a pregnancy that the unmarried college student had fearfully hidden from her family. She asphyxiated the newborn by wrapping him in a towel and plastic bag and then putting the bundle in the drawer of her bedroom dresser, actions that ''if not intentional, were certainly depraved'' or at least criminally negligent, an assistant district attorney said as the 20-year-old Canarsie woman went on trial on murder and other charges.

headline.main: Trial Begins For Woman In the Death Of Her Baby

docs.abstract: Karlie DiTrapani goes on trial for murdering her baby minutes after secretly giving birth to him in bathroom of her Brooklyn home; prosecutors contend that she is guilty of infanticide, while defense contends that baby was stillborn; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The way prosecutors told it in court yesterday, Karlie DiTrapani killed her baby minutes after secretly giving birth to him in a bathroom of her Brooklyn home, after a pregnancy that the unmarried college student had fearfully hidden from her family....

docs.lead_paragraph: Seeking to avert a bitter internal battle, Jim Nicholson, chairman of the Republican National Committee, today urged the party to scuttle a resolution denying money to candidates who oppose banning late-term abortions. Mr. Nicholson described himself as an abortion opponent and said he agreed with the party's platform that calls for prohibiting the type of abortions that occur late in a woman's pregnancy. But he said the resolution called for an improper litmus test that he suggested would undermine the ''big tent'' philosophy espoused by Lee Atwater, the late Republican chairman, who said the party should be broad enough for moderates on social and fiscal issues.

headline.main: Chairman of Republican National Committee Fights 'Litmus Test' on Abortion

docs.abstract: Republican National Committee chairman, Jim Nicholson, urges party to scuttle resolution denying money to candidates who oppose banning controversial late-term abortions; says he agrees with party platform that calls for ban on late-term procedure, but says resolution is improper litmus test that could undermine 'big tent' philosophy that party be broad enough for moderates on social and fiscal issues (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two Rutgers University professors are trying to determine what changes first-time mothers-to-be expect in their lives and how their expectations meet with reality once they have given birth. Warren Reich and Harold Siegel, psychology professors at the university's Newark campus, are looking for at least 40 women to go to the Newark campus for interviews and to fill out questionnaires. One interview would be conducted during the last trimester of pregnancy and a second a few months after the woman gives birth.

headline.main: Rutgers Studying Expectations Of Expectant Mothers

docs.abstract: Rutgers University Professors Warren Reich and Harold Siegel are studying what changes first-time mothers-to-be expect in lives and how their expectations are met once they give birth (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Raelene, a 34-year-old Australian whose ovaries were ruined by cancer treatments, tried for two years to find a woman in Australia who would donate eggs to her. But to no avail. Then she discovered the Egg Donor Program, a Los Angeles center run by Shelley Smith, a marriage, family and child counselor, that advertises that it has women who are willing to provide eggs and who are ''extremely bright, attractive and kindhearted.'' And, by the way, their intelligence test scores are available.

headline.main: Infertile Foreigners See Opportunity in U.S.

docs.abstract: US has become mecca for infertile foreigners who want donated sperm or eggs so they can try to have children; large commercial sperm banks offer to ship frozen semen around world using overnight delivery services; donated eggs, until recently available only through infertility doctors who recruited handful of donors for their own patients, are now also offered by centers that advertise hundreds of ready donors; eager customers pay over $100 for a semen sample and as much as $5,000 for eggs; experts say there are no guarantees that donor is as advertised and there have been some instances of consumer fraud; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Like so many other parents, they sent out a birth notice: ''Mario and Jane Simeone proudly announce the birth of their new arrivals!'' It listed the names of their triplets, the birth weights, lengths, and birth date: June 21, 1997. There were also color photographs, which conveyed what the words could not: Amber Raquel in the yellow light of a neonatal incubator, the word ''caution'' visible on its side; Cheyenne Barbara with tubes sprouting from chest, legs, arms and hands; Mario Victor with a ventilator tube taped to his mouth.

headline.main: Heartache Frequently Visits Parents With Multiple Births

docs.abstract: Joy surrounding birth of McCaughey septuplets in Des Moines compels some parents who have gone through difficult multiple births to disclose some of the heartache they have suffered; births of triplets, quadruplets and even quintuplets are becoming common thanks to new infertility treatments, and some of these pregnancies remain fraught with problems despite medical advances; parents involved in these pregnancies undergo frenzy of emotions; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: I always pass on good advice,'' Oscar Wilde wrote a century ago in ''An Ideal Husband.'' ''It is the only thing to do with it. It is never any use to oneself.'' With that in mind, we pass along to Rudolph W. Giuliani this counsel as he begins his second term as Mayor of New York. Sure, it's a lot to ask, but then again, he has four years to do it. We presume.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article of advice to Rudolph Giuliani in his second term as New York's mayor, from Floyd Flake, Stefanie Syman, Jerry Stiller and Anne Meara, Lisa Schiffren, Charles Rangel, Raymond Horton, George Stephanopoulos, Alanna Heiss, William Bratton, Hugh Fink, Lyn Pentecost, Ned Regan, Donald Trump, Mitchell Moss, Geoffrey Canada, Marcella Ross, Bella Abzug and Gabe Abelson; photo (S)
